messages: Hey there! Thanks for visiting Metro Boston HVAC. I'm here to help with whatever you've got going on with your heating or cooling. What can I help you with today?

options.label: My AC or heat isn't working

messages: I'm sorry you're dealing with that — I know how stressful it can be, especially when the weather isn't cooperating.
Can you tell me a bit more about what's happening?
No cold air is really common, and sometimes it's a quick fix. Here are a few things worth checking first:

1. Make sure your thermostat is set to COOL and the temperature is set below room temp.
2. Check if your air filter is clogged — a dirty filter can block airflow completely.
3. Take a look at your circuit breaker panel to see if anything tripped.
Were you able to check those, or is your home getting uncomfortably warm right now?
No heat can feel pretty urgent, especially during a New England winter. Let's see if we can narrow this down.

A couple things to check:
1. Is your thermostat set to HEAT and above room temperature?
2. If you have a furnace, check if the pilot light is on.
3. Make sure your air filter isn't clogged — that's one of the most common culprits.
4. Check your breaker panel for any tripped switches.
How are things feeling in the house right now?
Strange noises from your HVAC system are never fun. The good news is that the type of sound usually tells us a lot about what's going on.

Here's a quick guide:
• Banging or clanking — could be a loose or broken part inside the unit
• Squealing or screeching — often a belt or motor bearing issue
• Buzzing — may be an electrical component or a failing contactor
• Rattling — sometimes it's just a loose panel or ductwork
Is the system still heating/cooling okay, or has performance dropped too?
Water or leaking around your HVAC system should definitely be looked at. Here's what might be going on:

• Clogged condensate drain line — this is the most common cause and usually a straightforward fix
• Frozen evaporator coil — turn the system off and let it thaw, then check your filter
• Cracked drain pan — especially common in older units
If you see a lot of water, it's a good idea to turn the system off to prevent damage. Is the leak significant?

options.label: Yes, there's a lot of water

messages: A system that won't start can be a few things. Let's work through the basics:

1. Check your thermostat — make sure it's on and set correctly (sometimes batteries die)
2. Look at your circuit breaker panel for any tripped breakers
3. Check your furnace power switch (usually looks like a light switch near the unit)
4. If you have an outdoor unit, make sure nothing is blocking it
Any luck with those, or is it still not responding?

options.label: Tell me more about heat pumps

messages: Heat pumps are one of the smartest upgrades you can make for a New England home. Here's why folks love them:

• They heat AND cool — one system, year-round comfort
• Up to 3x more efficient than traditional furnaces
• Mass Save rebates can cover a significant portion of cost
• They work great even in cold Massachusetts winters (modern units are rated down to -15°F)
• Lower carbon footprint if that's important to you
We've installed hundreds of heat pump systems across the Metro Boston area. We'd be happy to do a free assessment of your home to recommend the right setup.
